Senior Class?
Move over Kreskin. The Senior Class, through one of those
quirks of fortune no mortal man can e'er understand, has for
a president a mentalist of amazing ability. Imagine the
possibilities; a new breed of mutant politico who can read the
minds of his constituents. Is it no wonder then that Frank
Faillace used this divine gift to determine just what faculty
speaker the senior class wanted for graduation? No doubt it is
much easier to use mystical powers than to call upon the
senior class for its opinion. Some may call this an
evolutionary
advancement; we just call it a plain case of
bungling arrogance.
We have no particular qualms about the selection of Dr.
Pfeffer as faculty speaker. However, the list of professors
suitable for presentation to the general public and parents is
quite long and certainly includes many other luminaries who
also give Hopkins its distinguished reputation. Apparently, if
we can find some method to the madness of Pfeffer's
selection, these other professors were never considered for the
honor. From what we can gather, Dr. Pfeffer had been
selected even before the graduation committee had been
formed. But such is the way of the mysterious visitor from
Long Island who passes himself off as an infallible mentalist.
The senior class looked forward to an exciting schedule of
events (social or otherwise) that would certainly make their
last year at Hopkins truly something they would never forget.
So far, it's been a real snoozer. We can not think.of anyone
but Frank Faillace responsible for this somnambulic
interlude. Seniors have been kept in the dark about all (if
any) plans for organized class activities. There have been
rumors that Frank has been planning a senior trip to Ocean
City for a wild weekend of merriment after the final final.
Not wishing to seem Bacchanalian poops, we would like to
think that there are better ways to celebrate the end of our
school days than a weekend on the beach drinking beer and
watching the tide gb out. Perhaps, we're nostalgic old fogies,
but we cherish memories of our high school's Senior Skip Day
when ten of us piled into a Mustang and sped off to Seaside
Heights, taking adolescent pleasure at putting one over on the
principal. We're not in high school anymore, Frank.

BY MIKE GIULIANO
The field of genetics is possibly the most exciting
area of scientific research. The quantity of genetic
information doubles every twenty-four months, and wnat
was once considered science fiction is rapidly becoming
fact. Test tube babies, cloning and sperm banks, until
recently the subject matter of futuristic novels like
Huxley's Brave New World, are now discussed in scientific
papers. As is so often the case, fact is proving to be

stranger, more incredible, than fiction.
Ted Howard and Jeremy Rifkin, members of the
People's Business Commission, a group opposed to
excessive corporate power, are among those wiio find
terrifying possibilities in current genetic research. Who
Should Play God? reflects their opposition to genetic
experimentation. Their arguments might be sound, and
they certainly have some frightening statistics and
speculations to support their position, but their book is a
badly organized, rambling mess. -It's the history of the
world and beyond--in 230 pages.
Of necessity, the discussion must be kept on a
general level, which makes for a rather hasty tour of
eugenics, recombinant DNA research, cloning, big
business, the Pentagon, and sundry other topics. And
their tour is poorly organized . After an opening discussion
of DNA, the tour bus backs up, and we're snown a quick
glimpse of eugenic nistory. The key names of that history,
Mendel, Darwin, Francis, Galton, the Kallikaks and the
Jukes, rush by in a blur, like neon signs reflected along a
rainy highway. Briefly, we are told that eugenics, revived
after the last war and renamed sociobiology, has
continued to find spokesmen, among them Jensen, who
believes that differences in intelligence are more directly
related to inheritance than to environment.
The two most important signposts on the tour are,
of course, the discovery of DNA in 1953 by James Watson
and Francis Crick, and the discovery of recombinant DNA
in 1973, a lab technique that fuses genetic material from
different organisms to create new life forms.
The research, while frightening in its possibilities, has
some amusing aspects. Cloning, for instance, is the

production of genetically identical individuals from a
single cell's biological information. It nas already been
done successfully with animals and vegetables. Woody
Allen experimented with cloning from a nose in Sleeper.
Howard and Rifkin wonder wiiat it would be like to
produce a clone of King Tut. Gunther Stent, writing in
Nature, speculates about a world of clones: while "it
would be fun to have Kant, Beethoven, Isadora Duncan,
Einstein, Clark Gable and Marilyn Monroe living on your
block, the thought of having hundreds of thousands of
their replicas in town is a nigatmare." Other speculations
in Who Should Play God? are just as delightfully
frightening.
All these speculations, however, are ultimately the
book's undoing. Too many sentences end with question
marks and exclamation points. Too many scare-tactic
quotations bore, rather than frighten, the reader. Harried
discussions of what role the Department of Defense,
business corporations and the National Academy of
Sciences play in genetic research are soon forgotten.

Move over Kreskin. The Senior Class, through one of those
quirks of fortune no mortal man can e'er understand, has for
a president a mentalist of amazing ability. Imagine the
possibilities; a new breed of mutant politico who can read the
minds of his constituents. Is it no wonder then that Frank
Faillace used this divine gift to determine just what faculty
speaker the senior class wanted for graduation? No doubt it is
much easier to use mystical powers than to call upon the
senior class for its opinion. Some may call this an
evolutionary
advancement; we just call it a plain case of
bungling arrogance.
We have no particular qualms about the selection of Dr.
Pfeffer as faculty speaker. However, the list of professors
suitable for presentation to the general public and parents is
quite long and certainly includes many other luminaries who
also give Hopkins its distinguished reputation. Apparently, if
we can find some method to the madness of Pfeffer's
selection, these other professors were never considered for the
honor. From what we can gather, Dr. Pfeffer had been
selected even before the graduation committee had been
formed. But such is the way of the mysterious visitor from
Long Island who passes himself off as an infallible mentalist.
The senior class looked forward to an exciting schedule of
events (social or otherwise) that would certainly make their
last year at Hopkins truly something they would never forget.
So far, it's been a real snoozer. We can not think.of anyone
but Frank Faillace responsible for this somnambulic
interlude. Seniors have been kept in the dark about all (if
any) plans for organized class activities. There have been
rumors that Frank has been planning a senior trip to Ocean
City for a wild weekend of merriment after the final final.

think that there are better ways to celebrate the end of our
school days than a weekend on the beach drinking beer and
watching the tide gb out. Perhaps, we're nostalgic old fogies,
but we cherish memories of our high school's Senior Skip Day

Heights, taking adolescent pleasure at putting one over on the
principal. We're not in high school anymore, Frank.

BY MIKE GIULIANO
The field of genetics is possibly the most exciting
area of scientific research. The quantity of genetic
information doubles every twenty-four months, and wnat
was once considered science fiction is rapidly becoming
fact. Test tube babies, cloning and sperm banks, until
recently the subject matter of futuristic novels like
Huxley's Brave New World, are now discussed in scientific
papers. As is so often the case, fact is proving to be

stranger, more incredible, than fiction.
Ted Howard and Jeremy Rifkin, members of the
People's Business Commission, a group opposed to
excessive corporate power, are among those wiio find
terrifying possibilities in current genetic research. Who
Should Play God? reflects their opposition to genetic
experimentation. Their arguments might be sound, and
they certainly have some frightening statistics and
speculations to support their position, but their book is a
badly organized, rambling mess. -It's the history of the
world and beyond--in 230 pages.
Of necessity, the discussion must be kept on a
general level, which makes for a rather hasty tour of
eugenics, recombinant DNA research, cloning, big
business, the Pentagon, and sundry other topics. And
their tour is poorly organized . After an opening discussion
of DNA, the tour bus backs up, and we're snown a quick
glimpse of eugenic nistory. The key names of that history,
Mendel, Darwin, Francis, Galton, the Kallikaks and the
Jukes, rush by in a blur, like neon signs reflected along a
rainy highway. Briefly, we are told that eugenics, revived
after the last war and renamed sociobiology, has
continued to find spokesmen, among them Jensen, who
believes that differences in intelligence are more directly
related to inheritance than to environment.
The two most important signposts on the tour are,
of course, the discovery of DNA in 1953 by James Watson
and Francis Crick, and the discovery of recombinant DNA
in 1973, a lab technique that fuses genetic material from
different organisms to create new life forms.
The research, while frightening in its possibilities, has
some amusing aspects. Cloning, for instance, is the

production of genetically identical individuals from a
single cell's biological information. It nas already been
done successfully with animals and vegetables. Woody
Allen experimented with cloning from a nose in Sleeper.
Howard and Rifkin wonder wiiat it would be like to
produce a clone of King Tut. Gunther Stent, writing in
Nature, speculates about a world of clones: while "it
would be fun to have Kant, Beethoven, Isadora Duncan,
Einstein, Clark Gable and Marilyn Monroe living on your
block, the thought of having hundreds of thousands of
their replicas in town is a nigatmare." Other speculations
in Who Should Play God? are just as delightfully
frightening.
All these speculations, however, are ultimately the
book's undoing. Too many sentences end with question
marks and exclamation points. Too many scare-tactic
quotations bore, rather than frighten, the reader. Harried
discussions of what role the Department of Defense,
business corporations and the National Academy of
Sciences play in genetic research are soon forgotten.

BIA returns
By PHILIP GILLY
If you are among those
students just back from a
vacation in Acapulco, Montego
Bay, Bimini, or as far away as
Fire Island, you are probably less
than enthusiastic about the start
of classes. Well, don't despair,
intramural basketball will soon
begin. Just a short trudge
through the snow and sleet and
rain to the Newton H. White
Athletic Center and you will find
an odd collection of the ABA,
the ACC, and the Harlem
Globetrotters performing on
Monday and Wednesday nights,
starting on January 30.
This year, in an effort to
increase interest, the BIA has
created a Division I for
high-caliber teams, and a Division
II for recreational teams. All
teams had the option of entering
the division which tney felt best
suited their level of play. There
will be four ten-team leagues, one
in Division I and three in Division
II. All participants are
undergraduates at Homewood,or
from JHMI. Graduate students

will play in their own league on
weekends, to be organized with
the help of the BIA.
The season is scneduled to run
until March 15 with games
starting at 7:00, 8:05, and 9:10
pm. There will be divisional
playoffs after tne regular season.
For any information, scheduling
conflicts, or extra copies of rules
and schedules, call Phil Gilly
(243-7609) or Terry Kaufman
(235-4197). Anybody still
interested in being a regular or a
replacement referee can contact
Ed Kasper (366-5610) or Bruce
Wolock (467-3320).
Other sports to look forward
to during February are Ping
Pong, Paddleball, Squash, and
Wrestling. Be sure to mark March
5 on your calendar -- tnis is the
last day to turn in rosters for BIA
lacrosse. Games will be played
almost exclusively on Sundays,
starting on March 12. This
schedule will reduce tne time
strain of playing three days a
week and improve the quality of
officials that are available, and
will increase the number of
games for each team.

A good grade
is within
your grasp.

The second semester, as
always, is the deciding factor in
the trophy point competition
because tnere are more events

event.

Lady Jays
Vastly
Improved
By RON BIALEK
Entering their fourth year of
intercollegiate play, the Johns
Hopkins Women's Basketball
team seems vastly improved and
highly determined With their new
coach, Barbara Bishop, and a
more experienced squad, this
year's team will supply their
opposition with some tough
competition.
Coach Bishop is generally
pleased with their progress thus
far The Blue Jays third game
against a tough Notre Dame
resulting in a 63-77 loss, showed
many offensive improvements
over their earlier games.
Captains of the team include
small forwards Rita Chang and
Monica Buescher along with
Carole Stafford in the tall
forward position. Rita. playing
her fourth year of college ball,
has proven to be a strong team
leader. "When I'm late for
practice or having some problems
getting things rolling, Rita really
can exert herself in a leadership
role," says coach Bishop.
This seasons' most improved
player has been point guard Lynn
Katz. Coach Bishop remarks,
"Off the bench Lynn has been a
very pleasant surprise."
